oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Goodrich School

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; Rural schools
Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; School buildings - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Dilapidated one-story structure made of vertical boards and tin roof. A chimney can be seen on the right side of the roof. A crude bench is in front of the building.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Education Schoolhouse Photos, 1938-1942
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This African American school had two classrooms, one teacher, and 56 students. The school was isolated, having no other schools nearby. Neither did it have a library, an encyclopedia, nor a dictionary. At least twenty-five cents a year was spent on each student but the structure itself was in very poor condition. Evidence of good housekeeping was observed. Evidently, the only source of heat was a fireplace at one end of the building.
